meaning: The idea that energy cannot be created or destroyed. If a reaction transfers energy to the surroundings the product molecules must have less energy than the reactants, by the amount transferred.
A reaction that transfers energy to the surroundings so the temperature of the surroundings increases.
A reaction that takes in energy from the surroundings so the temperature of the surroundings decreases.
The minimum amount of energy that particles must have to react.
The amount of energy required to break or form a particular type of covalent bond. Measured in kJ/mol.
A type of cell containing chemicals which react to produce electricity
A graph used to show the relative energies of reactants and products, the activation energy and the overall energy change of a reaction
A cell/battery where the reaction stops if one of the reactants is used up.
A cell/battery using a reaction that can be reversed when an external electrical current is supplied.
A type of cell supplied with an external source of fuel, which is oxidised electrochemically to produce a potential difference.
A type of fuel cell using hydrogen as fuel, which produces water as the only waste product.
